positive.review:
This game is systems within systems, absolute crack if you like numbers going up.
I've played it 60 hours at this point and I'm still constantly finding entire new systems of the game.

You can get insanely powerful and completely break the game turning into a god.

Tons of build options, probably the most character cosmetic visualization I've ever seen in a 2D game. Why download portraits when you can craft them yourself in-game?

Sect battles that play like mmo battlegrounds?
Your artifact can be possessed by some spirits collected through a gacha system....and then they all have levels, talent trees.

Manage a sect and play sect tournaments..once you become an elder it turns into a strategy game of picking the right people to do the fights.

The english version is really rough with some UI bugs, and the translation is far from great, but it doesn't really get in the way of playing the game.

I love this game, it has everything you want and so much more. At first I thought man it is not a good looking game, but does have nice partical effect, but the 2d can make it hard to see rocks on the ground that you don't see, but there is so much to the game not just with character developement but friends and disiple system is very cool. Normally I don't make friends in games, but in this I spend hours develeoping a friendship and disiples, that you can teach your skills to. This is a master piece and one of the best games in my libary. The combat is twinstick style and a lot of fun. Catch monsters is also a awesome layer, like pokemon but more fun, and they help you in battle.
It's fun, pretty ugly to look at sometimes, but definitely fun for what i got out of it.
Very good game, but has frequent visual bugs and the translation is still incomplete

So I enjoyed this game quite a bit. I enjoy the wuxia/ murim genre though so may have a bias. It has a bunch of cool little systems. Took me about 125 hours to beat on nightmare so it has a great amount of content, and the story is well written. Will probably come back to play on chaos again in the future wish i had played on chaos to begin with. 

Some tips
- Luck>insight>travel speed are the only stats that are fixed and you can't scale, travel speed matters the least out of the 3. Luck affects everything. Insight affects learning manuals you'll learn a lot but don't neccesarily need this only to shave time taken to learn manuals down. 

-You can save scum even if it deletes your file by alt f4ing during death cinematic if something really bad happens out of the blue so don't be afraid of harder modes.

- You can earn special starting traits from beating the game and achieving certain things. Like ending 1-4 gives new outfits and traits to pick at the start.

- [spoiler]When you become a sects grand elder you get a random message to become sect leader it isn't because he's in a higher sect. [/spoiler]

- [b]Most important [/b] When cultivating take your time to get the best possible items for your breakthrough! 

- On breakthroughs some of the destinies you add have tiers like bloodthirsty 1 2 3 you need to grab 1 at a lower cultivation rank then 2 and 3 if you plan to rewrite the destiny later. End game challenging shattered alter gives rewrites & so does the main story. 

- Artifact spirits! Breaking a pact with one takes 3 years before you can create a new pact! Also the more points you put into an spirit the more focus it costs to use them so check the wiki for talents!

Cons
- 1 Quest was completely untranslated
- Starting destiny lock is bugged for me
- few other translations missing like during sect tournament the ui buttons etc

Since I am into 修仙 dramas and movies these days, this game scratches that itch to play a game with the 修仙 theme considering the fact that there is not many games with the 修仙 theme on Steam. I am beginning to love games made by China-Chinese. As a single player game, the developer has made achievements achievable even if we use mods. And the game includes an easy to use modding tools that even I, who have zero knowledge in modding related skills, can create my own mods. Of course there is my all time favorite China-Chinese game feature, Steam achievements also unlock some in game rewards.

Tale of Immortal is what I would call the perfect Xianxia sandbox. Every mechanics interacts with each other to create novel-like scene and conflicts as if you're writing your own Xianxia novel. Play at your own pace, play anywhere from PC, Switch to mobile. It feels amazingly rich, especially as a single player escapism. 

The potential to MODing is vast too, create your own experience, and creating your own mod is like clicking several buttons. Please play it and check it out yourself if you love Xianxia genre
Never boring, always fun. Don't understand it? Roll with it and have an adventure you won't forget.

Best enjoyed if you add your own role play and limitations for your character, chaos difficulty simply cannot be beaten blind without guides and save scumming is a requirement. Great game with a crazy amount of variables to explore in game-play.
Great art and battle mechanics
Best game I ever played.Very recommand
Fox approves 10/10.
good game
more content when or when sequel ?:D
nice game

Go ahead. 

take the Lusterous Yang Elixir. 

What harm could it do?
NEW UPDATE WHEN T_T

As of Oct 2025, I would say perhaps 95% of the game is translated in english, including the five bloom DLC. The remaining 5% is on some minor dialogue and random sidequests, I think it's fine and I personally didn't miss out much on it, but your mileage may vary.

Regarding the game itself, this is my favourite Xianxia or Cultivator game thus far, the combat and sense of progression is done really well. It's not just "numbers go up" ala borderlands style, rather, each increase in cultivation rank brings about new gameplay options, such as artifacts, spirits, summoning dragons, etc.

The build diversity + power scaling is especially commendable, with 4 elements + 5 martial arts, each having 3 different basic, 6 special skill and 2 ultimates. I'm only 50 hours into the game and I already played more builds than i have in popular arpgs such as POE/Titan Quest/Diablo etc. Definitely well worth your money.

Story-wise, it's done well enough, the main story quest is a bit loose, you're dropped off into the world with little explanation, but the ending does stick pretty well and explains quite a bit(i did spoil myself on the ending). Something I wish was done better is the lack of linearity in obtaining quests, instead of the usual yellow exclaimation marks on NPCs in a central hub town, a lot of the well written quests were actually encountered randomly while traversing the world. Some may prefer this approach, but I always get the feeling like there's a whole bunch of quest that i missed, so it's not quite my cup of tea. However, the quests that I did encounter were well written and enjoyable.
The DLC story is a bit hit and miss, it adds 5 NPC lady companions with their own storyline. The first 2 that you encounter, the dimension traveller and the snow lady were definitely the highlights, while the other 3 could have been focused more on in later areas of the game. Instead, you meet them and do their quest bits and pieces throughout the game, making their storyline feel quite disjointed. But for a few extra dollars, i would still recommend it. Despite the glowing negative review on the DLC, many of which pointed out the lack of english translation, I'm happy to say that 95% of it was properly translated for me as of writing.

A huge negative is how grindly and lack of QOL the game seems to be intentionally doing. I do see what the developers are trying to do, but it's not for me. Thankfully, there are numerous english mods that solve this issue and make the game a lot more enjoyable. I would definitely recommend the following mods "Get forge items - KnightedWarrior", "God's eye - KnightedWarrior" and most importantly "Cheat Menu – Dynamic Multi-Language Support", just to solve certain grindy aspects. Even with mods and cheats, you'll likely still get 100+ hours out of the game.

Would definitely recommend.

You need to use this fix for the game to launch: (Win11) SETTINGS -> TIME & LANGUAGE -> LANGUAGE & REGION -> ADMINISTRATIVE LANGUAGE SETTINGS -> CHANGE SYSTEM LOCALE -> CHECKMARK: BETA: USE UNICODE UTF-8. 

If you delete the versions.dll (another fix I found but didn't use) you won't be able to use mods. This fix cleared it up for me immediately. That's really my only complaint about the game! After that, I've been having a baller time on this thing. 

No kidding, this game is great, and the mods make it even better. There's even in-game mods that you can load without using Nexus and stuff if you're less tech savvy. There's a lot of freedom to do whatever you want while also having objectives. The progression feels meaningful, but you can also grind endlessly if you'd prefer. You can get adopted parents and siblings and a spouse, too.

This game is systems within systems, absolute crack if you like numbers going up.
I've played it 60 hours at this point and I'm still constantly finding entire new systems of the game.

You can get insanely powerful and completely break the game turning into a god.

Tons of build options, probably the most character cosmetic visualization I've ever seen in a 2D game. Why download portraits when you can craft them yourself in-game?

Sect battles that play like mmo battlegrounds?
Your artifact can be possessed by some spirits collected through a gacha system....and then they all have levels, talent trees.

Manage a sect and play sect tournaments..once you become an elder it turns into a strategy game of picking the right people to do the fights.

The english version is really rough with some UI bugs, and the translation is far from great, but it doesn't really get in the way of playing the game.

Great game. I can finally become the Jade Beauty righteous hypocrite that is mentioned in the Holy Scriptures. Getting harassed by every random man that comes across me since I've got Divine Charisma. Truly peak.

not that good.
if you want to be stronger,you must go into a stable way,kill monsters to collect materials,go to city or somewhere,make things and eat it,be strong.
you will get in this way,maybe a shit loop,with some npc and good extra story.it is less like chinese fantasy,but more like American typical roat movie.
if the loop is hard for you,you can just ues a modifier to make your experience better,to get more focus in the game.

Translations is kind of bad, but the game itself is amazing for what it is. Stopped playing and the game have been updated a lot since, but I will probably come back to it eventually when I get the xianxia itch again.

This game is probably the best Xianxia RPG out there.

The translation is a bit wonky and/or awkward at times, as Chinese to English tends to be, but if you can look past this, the game has incredible depth to it.
You have 10 "Levels" of cultivation. 5 Areas, so 2 levels per area, which are seperated through a story relevant barrier and monster infested areas.

Every new area, you will want to look for new skills to grow stronger. You have your regular skill, LMB, to attack, you have a special skill RMB, which has a short cooldown of about 10 seconds, but can be reduced, you have a "Motion" skill, spacebar, which allows you to move around the arena, and you have an ultimate skill, R, which has a lengthy cooldown but can have powerful effects.

There are 12 Skill-trees (Sword, Blade, Spear, Finger, Palm, Fist, Fire, Water, Wood, Earth, Wind, Lightning) in total, and every attack I just described has multiple possible versions of it. For example, Lightning could learn a chain lightning skill, or shoot lightning orbs, or use a lightning whip to attack, and that's just one skill-tree and the LMB attack.

Every skill rolls a random set of sub-stats, the amount being dependant on the level and rarity of the skill, passive effects that affect this skill as well as your character. For Example, Motion Skills can roll "Agility", which is basically movement speed in an arena. So while you have this motion skill equipped, it provides you with bonus movement speed as well as it's active effect. The strength-cap on this effect is determined by the rarity and level of the skill as well. Red being rarest and grey being the weakest, classical A-RPG rarity system, you know the drill.

Obviously, you will want to have stronger skills, as a Level 1 skill will do very poorly against a Level 5 Enemy. On the other hand, a Level 5 Skill will more than likely oneshot a level 1 Enemy.

You are not locked in into your skill choices. You can make any kind of hybrid character you want, for example Sword-Wind or Spear-Lightning. There are, of course, synergies if you stay in your chosen skill-tree, but there can be some very powerful synergies if you think about existing effects, especially if you add the so-called Mind-Skills, which are entirely passive statboosters.

NPCs are randomly generated in a fixed world with a semi-randomized overlay. That means that the Towns generated will be in random spots across the map, sects created will have randomized skill-sets (I think?) and NPCs will be entirely random, but the layout of the world is always the same. NPCs can interact with you as much as you can with them. They  can ask you to be romantic with them, or they can choose to fight and kill you, just as much as you can do so towards them.

While travelling the world and living your best life as a cultivator, you will get sidequests which provide you both a concluding story, as well as more insight in the overall story, which is the mystery of the world. These sidequests can be short, one-part events like finding a wounded animal and deciding whether to nourish it back to health or finishing it off for potential treasure. You can be both good and evil in this game, both during these short events, as well as during the Main Story End Choices. There are FIVE different endings to the game, each with a unique boss fight. I won't spoiler though.

You can either join a sect and cultivate alongside them, raise through the ranks to eventually become the Sect Leader - or you can choose to remain on your own. (This is definitely a challenge run. If you attempt this, I recommend picking the Imp Gourd at the start, or getting Spiritual Fruits, which you need to increase your stats, will be cancer)

Most activities in the game, like Making Pills, Finding Treasure and learning new skill, have minigames associated with them. They are fun and non-intrusive the first few times, but they may become a little repetetive after a dozen or so times, but not to the point where I found them annoying.

Graphics-Wise, the game has gorgeous backgrounds that look almost handpainted in classical chinese fashion with the dynamic figures such as your player character and NPCs moving on them. The world map, too, looks hand drawn, but you won't see NPC-Models on there, just small numbers indicating they are there, as well as a bar on the top of the screen to see who is on the currently occupied square. That being said, every NPC has an avatar you can look at - and yes, the female avatars are attractive, it's not Concord.

The longer you play the deeper the game seems to get, continuously introducing new systems as you play. The only critique I have is that it's very easy to miss some of the stuff, but that might lead to your second playthrough becoming more interesting.

For the record: A single playthrough took me around 54 hours, and I knew what I was doing because I may or may not have played this game... elsewhere. It's very likely that your first playthrough might take between 80 and 100 hours all on it's own.

If you enjoy A-RPGs, Xianxia, don't mind the occassional grind, but you DO love to see yourself getting stronger to the point of oneshotting what once seemed to be an unsurmountable opponent, this is definitely worth your money and time. That being said: You don't get stronger in the classical RPG-fashion of killing mobs and gaining XP. Instead, you have to cultivate by absorbing Qi. This can be done easily inside a sect, or, if you aren't part of one, in the open world on blue-glowing spots.

If you are, however, looking for a mindless, easy and quick-to-get-into game to play, you might want to give this a pass. The tutorial teaches you only the very basics, and for everything else, the game respects your intelligence and relies on your curiosity.

My piece of advice: When you create your character, make sure you only push for Luck and Insight. Everything else can be raised ingame rather easily. But Luck and Insight can't, and they are crucial for your journey.
Insight determines how fast you learn skills and, minimally, how many "Rollback" Points you get when you reroll the Sub-Skill values.
Luck determines the quality and amount of Loot drops.
Both can cap out at 200. You probably want to start with around 100, preferrably more, in both.

And yes, the game has mod support, and yes, they are all Gooners.

this game is so unbelivably based

i do wish it was a tad more graphically intense, as to make the techniques more visually unique and interesting, but even then this game NAILS the vibes of wuxia and cultivation stories so well!!! and the gameplay is just fun!

it does feel like theres too much repetition with the boss fights, but its not enough to make it get boring. i do wish the game gave you different responses based on your temperment and stuff, and let you customize things about your character more directly, BUT randomized stats does make sense for a cultivation game, so it works!

best cultivation game, can't sum up everything in a single review. the npcs feel real, the alchemy, forging, talismans, and other crafting is unique. the gameplay is fun with an incredible amount of customization and fine tuning available.
The game is great. Maybe the combat style isn’t the best, but overall it’s pretty good.
Very unique sandbox game, definitely addictive. Has built in mods/community in game so pretty convenient.

This game has a alot to offer.
1. If your fan or very interested in the chinse mythology.
2. Visual is so well made.
3. Combat is not hard or easy.
4. Takes some time to learn, but not insanely long.
5. Moral system. (good/evil).
Lots of hours can be lost in the game, and yet every new game you make, you learn something.

minor problem, some translation is not done. (not sure if it is fixed when i write this review, since it been some time i last played.)

Excellent chinese xianxia rpg class game.

Minor frustation is the ring mission save bugs errors ie cannot enter city, event etc. player stats blank, game hang etc.  The supposed solution was to reload and avoid the ring quest.

A game with a lovely art direction, fun combat and a interesting dive into the world of Wuxia, marred by some weird balance and a incomplete translation.

It's still worth a play mind you.

The cultivation game I have been searching for, for years. Is the English a little broken...yes, but does that matter? Hell naw! This game has some grinding problems and it can be difficult at times but the world is quite open for exploration. I did search up some guides when I got super stuck like at the nascent realm cultivation. But overall it is definitely worth the money and even more so when it is on sale.

Tale of Immortal is a great fantasy simulation game, and I really enjoy playing it. However, I’d love to see a more inclusive romance system that allows relationships regardless of gender, as well as features like marriage, having children, and other unique side quests.

I also wish there were more ways to earn money besides fighting, completing quests, or selling items. Overall, I really like the game’s random story system it feels like you’re truly living as the character you’ve created and trained for years to become stronger. You get to experience different stories, meet friends and enemies, and enjoy a sense of freedom.

That said, the combat system and skill progression still feel a bit lacking. Once you master one skill, it takes a long time to develop the others. Though, to be fair, that makes sense if you consider how cultivation works in the novels it takes years for beginners to improve. I think the game would be even better if the combat felt more realistic, similar to typical action games.

The artwork is beautiful, but the fighting scenes feel quite different in style compared to the rest of the game. Still, I’ve seen some previews, and it seems like the developers are improving this aspect for the future.

One thing I don’t like is the text in the story windows it’s quite small and hard to read, which strains my eyes during long play sessions.

As for the quest information, some parts are still confusing and unclear. I’d like to see more detailed descriptions, such as objectives, city names, and information about people involved.

Overall, it’s a fun game. Even though it can get repetitive after playing for many in game years, I still recommend giving it a try.
RPG where your choice matter, relationship with NPCs matter, item/skill matter. Highly recommened.

Toothless Birth of a Legend !

Blazing with triumphs, I wandered into a new land, slaying beasts and seizing a wondrous tome. I emerged from the wastelands swollen with certainty of my own power. Then a figure approached, politely asking me to hand over the book. Convinced of my strength, I refused. Naturally, they stole the book anyway and vanished.

I scribbled down their impossible-to-remember name, plotting revenge. Imagine my surprise when this same trickster ran crying to their brother, accusing me of sharp words. The brother quickly explained that the wasteland I had just crawled out of was nothing more than a kids’ sandbox with plastic shovels—and soon enough I was picking up my teeth from the floor after meeting him. I thought I was immortal… turns out I was a chew toy for real cultivators

So if you ask me about the story in Tale of Immortal? Absolutely brilliant—if you’re ready to make up the story yourself and laugh at the chaos ;)

Highly recommended.
This game just like Crusader Kings. Both games make you wonder how to play for 10 hours.

As of Oct 2025, I would say perhaps 95% of the game is translated in english, including the five bloom DLC. The remaining 5% is on some minor dialogue and random sidequests, I think it's fine and I personally didn't miss out much on it, but your mileage may vary.

Regarding the game itself, this is my favourite Xianxia or Cultivator game thus far, the combat and sense of progression is done really well. It's not just "numbers go up" ala borderlands style, rather, each increase in cultivation rank brings about new gameplay options, such as artifacts, spirits, summoning dragons, etc.

The build diversity + power scaling is especially commendable, with 4 elements + 5 martial arts, each having 3 different basic, 6 special skill and 2 ultimates. I'm only 50 hours into the game and I already played more builds than i have in popular arpgs such as POE/Titan Quest/Diablo etc. Definitely well worth your money.

Story-wise, it's done well enough, the main story quest is a bit loose, you're dropped off into the world with little explanation, but the ending does stick pretty well and explains quite a bit(i did spoil myself on the ending). Something I wish was done better is the lack of linearity in obtaining quests, instead of the usual yellow exclaimation marks on NPCs in a central hub town, a lot of the well written quests were actually encountered randomly while traversing the world. Some may prefer this approach, but I always get the feeling like there's a whole bunch of quest that i missed, so it's not quite my cup of tea. However, the quests that I did encounter were well written and enjoyable.
The DLC story is a bit hit and miss, it adds 5 NPC lady companions with their own storyline. The first 2 that you encounter, the dimension traveller and the snow lady were definitely the highlights, while the other 3 could have been focused more on in later areas of the game. Instead, you meet them and do their quest bits and pieces throughout the game, making their storyline feel quite disjointed. But for a few extra dollars, i would still recommend it. Despite the glowing negative review on the DLC, many of which pointed out the lack of english translation, I'm happy to say that 95% of it was properly translated for me as of writing.

A huge negative is how grindly and lack of QOL the game seems to be intentionally doing. I do see what the developers are trying to do, but it's not for me. Thankfully, there are numerous english mods that solve this issue and make the game a lot more enjoyable. I would definitely recommend the following mods "Get forge items - KnightedWarrior", "God's eye - KnightedWarrior" and most importantly "Cheat Menu – Dynamic Multi-Language Support", just to solve certain grindy aspects. Even with mods and cheats, you'll likely still get 100+ hours out of the game.

Would definitely recommend.

If you delete the versions.dll (another fix I found but didn't use) you won't be able to use mods. This fix cleared it up for me immediately. That's really my only complaint about the game! After that, I've been having a baller time on this thing. 

No kidding, this game is great, and the mods make it even better. There's even in-game mods that you can load without using Nexus and stuff if you're less tech savvy. There's a lot of freedom to do whatever you want while also having objectives. The progression feels meaningful, but you can also grind endlessly if you'd prefer. You can get adopted parents and siblings and a spouse, too.

you will get in this way,maybe a shit loop,with some npc and good extra story.it is less like chinese fantasy,but more like American typical roat movie.
if the loop is hard for you,you can just ues a modifier to make your experience better,to get more focus in the game.

Translations is kind of bad, but the game itself is amazing for what it is. Stopped playing and the game have been updated a lot since, but I will probably come back to it eventually when I get the xianxia itch again.

This game is probably the best Xianxia RPG out there.

The translation is a bit wonky and/or awkward at times, as Chinese to English tends to be, but if you can look past this, the game has incredible depth to it.
You have 10 "Levels" of cultivation. 5 Areas, so 2 levels per area, which are seperated through a story relevant barrier and monster infested areas.

Every new area, you will want to look for new skills to grow stronger. You have your regular skill, LMB, to attack, you have a special skill RMB, which has a short cooldown of about 10 seconds, but can be reduced, you have a "Motion" skill, spacebar, which allows you to move around the arena, and you have an ultimate skill, R, which has a lengthy cooldown but can have powerful effects.

There are 12 Skill-trees (Sword, Blade, Spear, Finger, Palm, Fist, Fire, Water, Wood, Earth, Wind, Lightning) in total, and every attack I just described has multiple possible versions of it. For example, Lightning could learn a chain lightning skill, or shoot lightning orbs, or use a lightning whip to attack, and that's just one skill-tree and the LMB attack.

Every skill rolls a random set of sub-stats, the amount being dependant on the level and rarity of the skill, passive effects that affect this skill as well as your character. For Example, Motion Skills can roll "Agility", which is basically movement speed in an arena. So while you have this motion skill equipped, it provides you with bonus movement speed as well as it's active effect. The strength-cap on this effect is determined by the rarity and level of the skill as well. Red being rarest and grey being the weakest, classical A-RPG rarity system, you know the drill.

Obviously, you will want to have stronger skills, as a Level 1 skill will do very poorly against a Level 5 Enemy. On the other hand, a Level 5 Skill will more than likely oneshot a level 1 Enemy.

You are not locked in into your skill choices. You can make any kind of hybrid character you want, for example Sword-Wind or Spear-Lightning. There are, of course, synergies if you stay in your chosen skill-tree, but there can be some very powerful synergies if you think about existing effects, especially if you add the so-called Mind-Skills, which are entirely passive statboosters.

NPCs are randomly generated in a fixed world with a semi-randomized overlay. That means that the Towns generated will be in random spots across the map, sects created will have randomized skill-sets (I think?) and NPCs will be entirely random, but the layout of the world is always the same. NPCs can interact with you as much as you can with them. They  can ask you to be romantic with them, or they can choose to fight and kill you, just as much as you can do so towards them.

While travelling the world and living your best life as a cultivator, you will get sidequests which provide you both a concluding story, as well as more insight in the overall story, which is the mystery of the world. These sidequests can be short, one-part events like finding a wounded animal and deciding whether to nourish it back to health or finishing it off for potential treasure. You can be both good and evil in this game, both during these short events, as well as during the Main Story End Choices. There are FIVE different endings to the game, each with a unique boss fight. I won't spoiler though.

You can either join a sect and cultivate alongside them, raise through the ranks to eventually become the Sect Leader - or you can choose to remain on your own. (This is definitely a challenge run. If you attempt this, I recommend picking the Imp Gourd at the start, or getting Spiritual Fruits, which you need to increase your stats, will be cancer)

Most activities in the game, like Making Pills, Finding Treasure and learning new skill, have minigames associated with them. They are fun and non-intrusive the first few times, but they may become a little repetetive after a dozen or so times, but not to the point where I found them annoying.

Graphics-Wise, the game has gorgeous backgrounds that look almost handpainted in classical chinese fashion with the dynamic figures such as your player character and NPCs moving on them. The world map, too, looks hand drawn, but you won't see NPC-Models on there, just small numbers indicating they are there, as well as a bar on the top of the screen to see who is on the currently occupied square. That being said, every NPC has an avatar you can look at - and yes, the female avatars are attractive, it's not Concord.

The longer you play the deeper the game seems to get, continuously introducing new systems as you play. The only critique I have is that it's very easy to miss some of the stuff, but that might lead to your second playthrough becoming more interesting.

For the record: A single playthrough took me around 54 hours, and I knew what I was doing because I may or may not have played this game... elsewhere. It's very likely that your first playthrough might take between 80 and 100 hours all on it's own.

If you enjoy A-RPGs, Xianxia, don't mind the occassional grind, but you DO love to see yourself getting stronger to the point of oneshotting what once seemed to be an unsurmountable opponent, this is definitely worth your money and time. That being said: You don't get stronger in the classical RPG-fashion of killing mobs and gaining XP. Instead, you have to cultivate by absorbing Qi. This can be done easily inside a sect, or, if you aren't part of one, in the open world on blue-glowing spots.

If you are, however, looking for a mindless, easy and quick-to-get-into game to play, you might want to give this a pass. The tutorial teaches you only the very basics, and for everything else, the game respects your intelligence and relies on your curiosity.

My piece of advice: When you create your character, make sure you only push for Luck and Insight. Everything else can be raised ingame rather easily. But Luck and Insight can't, and they are crucial for your journey.
Insight determines how fast you learn skills and, minimally, how many "Rollback" Points you get when you reroll the Sub-Skill values.
Luck determines the quality and amount of Loot drops.
Both can cap out at 200. You probably want to start with around 100, preferrably more, in both.

And yes, the game has mod support, and yes, they are all Gooners.

this game is so unbelivably based

i do wish it was a tad more graphically intense, as to make the techniques more visually unique and interesting, but even then this game NAILS the vibes of wuxia and cultivation stories so well!!! and the gameplay is just fun!

it does feel like theres too much repetition with the boss fights, but its not enough to make it get boring. i do wish the game gave you different responses based on your temperment and stuff, and let you customize things about your character more directly, BUT randomized stats does make sense for a cultivation game, so it works!

So I enjoyed this game quite a bit. I enjoy the wuxia/ murim genre though so may have a bias. It has a bunch of cool little systems. Took me about 125 hours to beat on nightmare so it has a great amount of content, and the story is well written. Will probably come back to play on chaos again in the future wish i had played on chaos to begin with. 

Some tips
- Luck>insight>travel speed are the only stats that are fixed and you can't scale, travel speed matters the least out of the 3. Luck affects everything. Insight affects learning manuals you'll learn a lot but don't neccesarily need this only to shave time taken to learn manuals down. 

-You can save scum even if it deletes your file by alt f4ing during death cinematic if something really bad happens out of the blue so don't be afraid of harder modes.

- You can earn special starting traits from beating the game and achieving certain things. Like ending 1-4 gives new outfits and traits to pick at the start.

- [spoiler]When you become a sects grand elder you get a random message to become sect leader it isn't because he's in a higher sect. [/spoiler]

- [b]Most important [/b] When cultivating take your time to get the best possible items for your breakthrough! 

- On breakthroughs some of the destinies you add have tiers like bloodthirsty 1 2 3 you need to grab 1 at a lower cultivation rank then 2 and 3 if you plan to rewrite the destiny later. End game challenging shattered alter gives rewrites & so does the main story. 

- Artifact spirits! Breaking a pact with one takes 3 years before you can create a new pact! Also the more points you put into an spirit the more focus it costs to use them so check the wiki for talents!

Cons
- 1 Quest was completely untranslated
- Starting destiny lock is bugged for me
- few other translations missing like during sect tournament the ui buttons etc
Never boring, always fun. Don't understand it? Roll with it and have an adventure you won't forget.

I love this game, it has everything you want and so much more. At first I thought man it is not a good looking game, but does have nice partical effect, but the 2d can make it hard to see rocks on the ground that you don't see, but there is so much to the game not just with character developement but friends and disiple system is very cool. Normally I don't make friends in games, but in this I spend hours develeoping a friendship and disiples, that you can teach your skills to. This is a master piece and one of the best games in my libary. The combat is twinstick style and a lot of fun. Catch monsters is also a awesome layer, like pokemon but more fun, and they help you in battle.
It's fun, pretty ugly to look at sometimes, but definitely fun for what i got out of it.

A must buy if you're a fan of the Wuxia Cultivation type games. It's pretty deep and a bit of a grind but I like these types of games. I liked becoming a Sect leader and raiding other sects. Again if you don't like these type of games you probably won't like it there are some translation errors but all in all I enjoyed it

best cultivation game, can't sum up everything in a single review. the npcs feel real, the alchemy, forging, talismans, and other crafting is unique. the gameplay is fun with an incredible amount of customization and fine tuning available.
The game is great. Maybe the combat style isn’t the best, but overall it’s pretty good.
Very unique sandbox game, definitely addictive. Has built in mods/community in game so pretty convenient.

This game has a alot to offer.
1. If your fan or very interested in the chinse mythology.
2. Visual is so well made.
3. Combat is not hard or easy.
4. Takes some time to learn, but not insanely long.
5. Moral system. (good/evil).
Lots of hours can be lost in the game, and yet every new game you make, you learn something.

minor problem, some translation is not done. (not sure if it is fixed when i write this review, since it been some time i last played.)

Excellent chinese xianxia rpg class game.

Minor frustation is the ring mission save bugs errors ie cannot enter city, event etc. player stats blank, game hang etc.  The supposed solution was to reload and avoid the ring quest.
Very good game, but has frequent visual bugs and the translation is still incomplete

Since I am into 修仙 dramas and movies these days, this game scratches that itch to play a game with the 修仙 theme considering the fact that there is not many games with the 修仙 theme on Steam. I am beginning to love games made by China-Chinese. As a single player game, the developer has made achievements achievable even if we use mods. And the game includes an easy to use modding tools that even I, who have zero knowledge in modding related skills, can create my own mods. Of course there is my all time favorite China-Chinese game feature, Steam achievements also unlock some in game rewards.

Best enjoyed if you add your own role play and limitations for your character, chaos difficulty simply cannot be beaten blind without guides and save scumming is a requirement. Great game with a crazy amount of variables to explore in game-play.

so fun so much thing to do pls checkl out thí game it í really fun anđ iam bneing so foreal  i đint get payed to say this, this game work on almost every pc because of how light it is my pc is a ofice pc and can still run this game very smooth rbh iam being so forela pls check this game ouy

negative.review: Too many errors. cannot enter city, event etc. player stats blank, game hang etc.  Very frustating to play and difficult to recommend. The supposed solution was to reload but it keep happening even when i skip the ring quest.
Wide in scope, shallow in substance—to many menus, dry text, and dull combat. Maybe it gets better late game but i'm not willing to get there

I think this game is great, but frankly its been years and the game still isn't completely translated yet.  There are many events that they still haven't gotten around to translating.  So as an English speaking customer I can't recommend this.  Now if you can read chinese then yes I'd highly recommend.  I'll re-review it once everything has been translated but the last time I got to the end it was some pretty bad translated dialog which you can't have when most people aren't familiar with this genre.

As a product, the game itself shows exceptional promise; however, its development team has, regrettably, failed to capitalize on that potential. Despite numerous player reports of bugs and other issues, no substantive updates or fixes have been communicated. The apparent absence of any response raises serious concerns about the team’s priorities and operational effectiveness.

I wish it was a middle option, but the game got alot of UI bugs and random translation errors. But these sorta games are awesome if you are into cultivation games.

The combat is meh, but i like the feel of the game.
Wide in scope, shallow in substance—to many menus, dry text, and dull combat. Maybe it gets better late game but i'm not willing to get there
has game breaking bug that maks thee game unplayable
can't even start the game without deleting version.dll

I think this game is great, but frankly its been years and the game still isn't completely translated yet.  There are many events that they still haven't gotten around to translating.  So as an English speaking customer I can't recommend this.  Now if you can read chinese then yes I'd highly recommend.  I'll re-review it once everything has been translated but the last time I got to the end it was some pretty bad translated dialog which you can't have when most people aren't familiar with this genre.

As a product, the game itself shows exceptional promise; however, its development team has, regrettably, failed to capitalize on that potential. Despite numerous player reports of bugs and other issues, no substantive updates or fixes have been communicated. The apparent absence of any response raises serious concerns about the team’s priorities and operational effectiveness.
